metadata.subject: biology
metadata.dotPoint: The structure of nucleotides as monomers of nucleic acids, including the structure of DNA and RNA and the role of complementary base pairing

nucleotide_components.name: Nucleotide Components
nucleotide_components.correct: A nucleotide has three components: a phosphate group, a pentose sugar, and a nitrogenous base.

amino acid.error: Amino acids build proteins, not nucleic acids.
amino acid.fix: Nucleotides are the monomers of nucleic acids. Amino acids are for proteins.
amino acid.action: Make a table: DNA/RNA â†’ nucleotides. Proteins â†’ amino acids.

monosaccharide.error: Monosaccharides are simple sugars, not complete nucleotide monomers.
monosaccharide.fix: A pentose sugar is ONE component of a nucleotide, not the whole thing.
monosaccharide.action: List all three parts: phosphate + sugar + base = nucleotide.

fatty acid.error: Fatty acids are components of lipids, not nucleic acids.
fatty acid.fix: Fatty acids build fats. Nucleotides build DNA and RNA.
fatty acid.action: Match macromolecules to monomers: nucleic acid â†’ nucleotide.

persistent.gap: You're confusing monomers of different macromolecules.
persistent.action: Create flashcards: Nucleic acids (nucleotides), Proteins (amino acids), Lipids (fatty acids/glycerol).

pentose_sugar_type.name: Pentose Sugar in Nucleotides
pentose_sugar_type.correct: DNA contains deoxyribose (missing 2'-OH). RNA contains ribose (has 2'-OH).

glucose.error: Glucose is a hexose (6C), not a pentose (5C).
glucose.fix: Nucleotides use pentose sugars with 5 carbons, not glucose.
glucose.action: Count carbons: glucose has 6, ribose/deoxyribose have 5.

sucrose.error: Sucrose is a disaccharide, not a nucleotide component.
sucrose.fix: Nucleotides contain simple 5-carbon sugars, not complex sugars.
sucrose.action: Sucrose = table sugar. Ribose = RNA sugar. Different molecules.

galactose.error: Galactose is a hexose found in dairy, not nucleotides.
galactose.fix: Only pentose sugars (5C) are found in nucleic acids.

persistent.gap: You don't know which sugars are in nucleotides.
persistent.action: Memorise: DNA = DeoxyriboNucleic Acid (deoxyribose). RNA = RiboNucleic Acid (ribose).

nitrogenous_bases.name: Nitrogenous Bases
nitrogenous_bases.correct: Purines (adenine, guanine) have two rings. Pyrimidines (cytosine, thymine, uracil) have one ring.

purines have one ring.error: Reversed. Purines have TWO rings, pyrimidines have one.
purines have one ring.fix: PURe As Gold = Purines are Adenine and Guanine (double ring).
purines have one ring.action: Draw them: A and G are larger (2 rings). C, T, U are smaller (1 ring).

thymine is a purine.fix: Only A and G are purines. C, T, and U are pyrimidines.
thymine is a purine.action: Memorise: Purines = A, G (bigger). Pyrimidines = C, T, U (smaller).

uracil is in DNA.error: Uracil is in RNA only. DNA uses thymine.
uracil is in DNA.fix: DNA = A, T, G, C. RNA = A, U, G, C. T and U swap.
uracil is in DNA.action: T for DNA, U for RNA. Both pair with adenine.

persistent.gap: You're confusing which bases are purines vs pyrimidines, or DNA vs RNA.
persistent.action: Make two lists: Purines (A, G - 2 rings) and Pyrimidines (C, T, U - 1 ring).

double_helix_structure.name: DNA Double Helix
double_helix_structure.correct: DNA is a double helix with two antiparallel strands connected by hydrogen bonds between bases.

parallel strands.error: DNA strands are antiparallel, running in opposite directions.
parallel strands.fix: One strand runs 5'â†’3', the other runs 3'â†’5'.
parallel strands.action: Draw DNA: label 5' and 3' ends. Notice they're opposite on each strand.

covalent bonds between bases.error: Bases are joined by hydrogen bonds, which are weak.
covalent bonds between bases.fix: Weak H-bonds let strands separate for replication. Covalent bonds are in the backbone.
covalent bonds between bases.action: H-bonds = between strands (weak). Covalent = within backbone (strong).

single stranded.error: DNA is double-stranded. RNA is typically single-stranded.
single stranded.fix: Watson and Crick discovered DNA's DOUBLE helix structure.
single stranded.action: DNA = double helix. RNA = usually single strand that can fold.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the double helix structure.
persistent.action: Draw a DNA ladder: uprights = sugar-phosphate, rungs = base pairs, twist it.

complementary_base_pairing.name: Base Pairing Rules
complementary_base_pairing.correct: Adenine pairs with thymine (2 H-bonds). Guanine pairs with cytosine (3 H-bonds).

adenine pairs with guanine.error: A pairs with T, not G. Two purines can't pair together.
adenine pairs with guanine.fix: Purine always pairs with pyrimidine. A(purine)-T(pyrimidine), G(purine)-C(pyrimidine).
adenine pairs with guanine.action: A-T, G-C. Always big + small = consistent helix width.

cytosine pairs with thymine.error: C pairs with G, not T. Two pyrimidines can't pair together.
cytosine pairs with thymine.fix: C and T are both pyrimidines (small). They need purines as partners.
cytosine pairs with thymine.action: G-C always. A-T always. No exceptions in normal DNA.

all pairs have 2 hydrogen bonds.error: G-C has 3 hydrogen bonds, A-T has only 2.
all pairs have 2 hydrogen bonds.fix: G-C is stronger (3 H-bonds). High G-C content = harder to separate.

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised base pairing rules.
persistent.action: Flashcard: A-T (2 bonds), G-C (3 bonds). Test yourself 10 times.

sugar_phosphate_backbone.name: Sugar-Phosphate Backbone
sugar_phosphate_backbone.correct: The backbone consists of alternating sugar and phosphate groups linked by phosphodiester bonds.

peptide bonds.error: Peptide bonds link amino acids, not nucleotides.
peptide bonds.fix: Phosphodiester bonds link nucleotides. Peptide bonds are in proteins.
peptide bonds.action: Match: proteins = peptide bonds. Nucleic acids = phosphodiester bonds.

hydrogen bonds.error: H-bonds are between bases, not in the backbone.
hydrogen bonds.fix: Backbone = strong covalent (phosphodiester). Between strands = weak H-bonds.
hydrogen bonds.action: Backbone holds one strand together. H-bonds hold two strands together.

glycosidic bonds.error: Glycosidic bonds link sugars in carbohydrates.
glycosidic bonds.fix: The bond between nucleotides is a phosphodiester bond.

persistent.gap: You're confusing bond types in different macromolecules.
persistent.action: Make a bond table: Proteins (peptide), Nucleic acids (phosphodiester), Carbs (glycosidic).

dna_vs_rna_differences.name: DNA vs RNA Differences
dna_vs_rna_differences.correct: DNA: deoxyribose, thymine, double-stranded, stable. RNA: ribose, uracil, single-stranded, less stable.

RNA is double-stranded.error: RNA is typically single-stranded. DNA is double-stranded.
RNA is double-stranded.fix: RNA can fold on itself but is made as a single strand.
RNA is double-stranded.action: DNA = permanent storage (double). RNA = temporary message (single).

DNA contains uracil.error: DNA uses thymine. RNA uses uracil.
DNA contains uracil.fix: T is only in DNA. U is only in RNA. Both pair with A.
DNA contains uracil.action: Memorise: DNA = T, RNA = U. They're functionally equivalent.

RNA is more stable than DNA.error: DNA is more stable due to deoxyribose and double-strand structure.
RNA is more stable than DNA.fix: The 2'-OH in ribose makes RNA prone to hydrolysis.
RNA is more stable than DNA.action: DNA = long-term storage. RNA = short-lived messenger.

persistent.gap: You're mixing up DNA and RNA characteristics.
persistent.action: Make comparison table: DNA vs RNA for sugar, bases, strands, stability.

directionality_5_to_3.name: 5' to 3' Directionality
directionality_5_to_3.correct: DNA strands have direction based on sugar carbons. Synthesis always proceeds 5' to 3'.

synthesis is 3' to 5'.error: Reversed. New nucleotides are added to the 3' end.
synthesis is 3' to 5'.fix: DNA polymerase adds nucleotides to the 3'-OH group only.
synthesis is 3' to 5'.action: Rule: read template 3'â†’5', synthesise new strand 5'â†’3'.

direction doesn't matter.error: Directionality is critical for replication enzymes.
direction doesn't matter.fix: Enzymes can only work in one direction, creating leading/lagging strands.
direction doesn't matter.action: This is why one strand is continuous and one is in fragments.

both directions are equal.fix: No enzyme can add nucleotides to the 5' end.
both directions are equal.action: All DNA polymerases work 5' to 3'. No exceptions.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why directionality matters.
persistent.action: Draw replication fork. Label leading strand (continuous) and lagging strand (fragments).

nucleotide_components.title: Nucleotide Structure
nucleotide_components.content: Nucleotides are the monomers of nucleic acids. Each nucleotide has three components: a phosphate group (provides negative charge and links nucleotides), a pentose sugar (deoxyribose in DNA, ribose in RNA), and a nitrogenous base (carries genetic information).

pentose_sugar_type.title: DNA and RNA Sugars
pentose_sugar_type.content: DNA contains deoxyribose, which lacks an oxygen at the 2' carbon (hence 'deoxy'). RNA contains ribose with a hydroxyl group at 2'. This difference affects stability - DNA is more stable for long-term storage, while RNA is more reactive.

nitrogenous_bases.title: Nitrogenous Bases
nitrogenous_bases.content: Purines (adenine, guanine) have two fused rings. Pyrimidines (cytosine, thymine, uracil) have one ring. DNA uses A, T, G, C; RNA uses A, U, G, C. Thymine and uracil both pair with adenine.
keyPoints: T is in DNA; U is in RNA

double_helix_structure.title: DNA Double Helix
double_helix_structure.content: DNA forms a double helix with two antiparallel strands. The sugar-phosphate backbone is on the outside; bases point inward and pair through hydrogen bonds. This structure allows replication through strand separation.

complementary_base_pairing.title: Base Pairing Rules
complementary_base_pairing.content: Adenine pairs with thymine (or uracil) through 2 hydrogen bonds. Guanine pairs with cytosine through 3 hydrogen bonds. A purine always pairs with a pyrimidine, maintaining consistent helix width.

sugar_phosphate_backbone.title: Sugar-Phosphate Backbone
sugar_phosphate_backbone.content: The backbone consists of alternating sugar and phosphate groups linked by phosphodiester bonds. The phosphate connects the 5' carbon of one sugar to the 3' carbon of the next. This creates the 5' to 3' directionality.

dna_vs_rna_differences.title: DNA vs RNA
dna_vs_rna_differences.content: Key differences: DNA has deoxyribose, thymine, is double-stranded, and stable. RNA has ribose, uracil, is usually single-stranded, and less stable. DNA stores genetic information; RNA carries it out.
keyPoints: RNA: ribose, U, single, less stable

directionality_5_to_3.title: 5' to 3' Direction
directionality_5_to_3.content: DNA strands have directionality based on the 5' and 3' carbons of the sugar. The 5' end has a free phosphate; the 3' end has a free hydroxyl. All DNA synthesis proceeds 5' to 3'.
